subject: Career
title: Signal vs. Noise in Messages
description: A micro-lesson that makes Signal vs. Noise in Messages usable.

hook.text: A 500-word email where the actual request is buried in paragraph four. Your signal is drowning in noise.

buildup.text: Shannon's information theory applies: every message has signal (useful info) and noise (everything else).

discovery.text: High-signal communication means every word earns its place. No filler, no preamble, no hedging.

twist.text: People add noise for comfort: disclaimers, softeners, backstory. But the reader just wants the point.

climax.text: Write your message. Then cut it in half. The remaining words are probably all that was needed.

punchline.text: Say less. Mean more. Get heard.

quiz.question: What is 'noise' in workplace communication?
options: Unnecessary filler that buries the actual message
